instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PLT_RESET_L: What is PLT_RESET_L? PLT_RESET_L is platform reset, this signal keeps the system from POSTing. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.PPVCC_S0_CPU: What is PPVCC_S0_CPU? The "PPVCC_S0_CPU" power rail is responsible for supplying power to the CPU when the MacBook is fully on, or in the S0 state. This rail is one of the main voltages that the CPU requires for operation. .
definitions.EDP_BKLT_EN: What is EDP_BKLT_EN? This is an enable signal. Anytime you see “_EN”, it means when the voltage is high(3.3 volts), whatever it is going to is being turned on or enabled. Here, “EDP_BKLT” which stands for “embedded displayport backlight” is being enabled. This signal usually goes to an LED driver used for creating a power rail for the LCD screen backlight, to tell it to turn on & create this rail. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A, no backlight
threads.message:
Hi all,

A newbie here so bear with me if I ask something silly.

<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A with no major apparent issues other than the backlight is not working, if this is the real issue.

When connected to the charger, outside the case, the flex cable is removed, drawing 530-550 mA constantly, the CPU gets warm, and the fan starts well however it reaches full speed in about 10-15 seconds.

<SIGNAL>PPVIN_S0SW_LCDBKLT_FET</SIGNAL> = 0.0v

F7700 good
<RESISTOR>R7788</RESISTOR>, <RESISTOR>R7789</RESISTOR> are good

No <SIGNAL>EDP_BKLT_EN</SIGNAL> at <TRANSISTOR>Q7707</TRANSISTOR>, it is 0.0v, no short to ground as far as I can see
<RESISTOR>R1430</RESISTOR> (100k) 0.0v

This is the bit I got a bit lost, <SIGNAL>EDP_BKLT_EN</SIGNAL> is generated at <CHIP>U0500</CHIP> as far as I can say, the CPU?
<SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL> is high at 3.3v
<SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> is at 1.8v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A, no backlight
threads.message:
First of all, welcome to the forum!

Do you get image for sure, only missing backlighT?
Tested external video and USB activity?

threads.message:

First of all, welcome to the forum!

Good point, no video when I connect a screen via HDMI, so I suppose it is not a backlight issue.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A, no backlight
threads.message:
Did you test for USB activity?
If not detected, your problem is not video related.

Any history available?
<SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL> goes high?

BTW, write directly into reply box (below the last post) instead of clicking Reply button.
No need to quote an entire post, visible few centimeters above.
Please, maintain forum aesthetic...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A, no backlight
threads.message:
You are right, when I saw 500+ mA draw, warm CPU and fan spin I wrongly assumed that the issues was display related.

Yes, I measure <SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL> at 3.3v and if relevant <SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> is at 1.8v. How can I further check that the CPU is actually running?

Re: Replies, noted, will do.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A, no backlight
threads.message:
"Any history available?"
???

Check all SPI Bus Series Termination resistors and their traces.
Inspect J6100 for corrosion.
You can try known good BIOS.
